Graphs

1. The Cartesian plane

Points on the Cartesian plane

The picture below shows the Cartesian plane and four points. The points are labelled A,B,CA,B,C and DD.

Which of the points has the coordinates (−4;0)(−4;0)?

Answer: The point at (−4;0)(−4;0) is:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Coordinate pairs always show the xx-value first and the yy-value second. That means that the coordinates (−4;0)(−4;0) refer to the point where x=−4x=−4 and y=0y=0.

STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

There are four points shown in the picture above, and we must decide which of the points has the coordinates (−4;0)(−4;0). Coordinate pairs always show the xx-coordinate first and the yy-coordinate second. In this case that means that x=−4x=−4 and y=0y=0.

To find where the point is, we always start at the centre point, which is called the "origin." From there, the coordinates tell us how far to go and in which directions:

  • the xx-coordinate tells us how far to move left or right (along the xx-axis); if x=0x=0, do not move left or right
  • the yy-coordinate tells us how far to move up or down (along the yy-axis); if y=0y=0, do not move up or down

There is an arrow on the graph below which shows how to get from the origin to the point at the coordinates (−4;0)(−4;0).

Start with the xx value. For the coordinates (−4;0)(−4;0), xx is −4−4: that means go 44 steps to the left (we go left because the coordinate is negative). After the xx coordinate, we do what the yy coordinate tells us to do: the yy coordinate is zero, which means that we do not move up or down: just stay put!

The point at the coordinates (−4;0)(−4;0) is point A.

Submit your answer as:

Coordinates on the Cartesian plane

Four points, labelled M,N,PM,N,P and QQ, are shown below. Answer the two questions below based on this figure.

  1. What is the xx-coordinate of Point QQ?

    Answer: The xx-coordinate of Point QQ is:
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Notice that you only the xx-coordinate for the point. Remember that the xx-value for the point tells you how far to the left or right the point is from the origin.

    STEP: Start at the origin and find the xx-coordinate of Point QQ
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need the xx-coordinate of Point QQ. There are different ways to think about this question, so you might solve it differently to the explanation here.

    Remember that the xx-coordinate for the point tells us how far to the left or right the point is from the origin. The vertical line below passes through Point QQ: we can use the line to figure out how far to the right the point is from the origin.

    As noted in the picture, the vertical line shows that Point QQ is 33 spaces to the right of the origin. In fact, any point on that line is 33 spaces to the right of the origin. That means that the xx-coordinate must be 33.

    The xx-coordinate of Point QQ is: x=3x=3.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. How many labelled points are there in the second quadrant?

    Answer: The number of labelled points is:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
    The question specifically asks us to count how many labelled points are in the second quadrant. The graph shows points M,N,PM,N,P and QQ: how many of them are "in the second quadrant?"
    STEP: Consider the labelled points on the plane
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to figure out how many labelled points there are in the second quadrant. There are only four labelled points in the diagram: how many of them are in the second quadrant?

    In this question, the four points M,N,PM,N,P and QQ are labelled, but they are not the only points on the graph. The Cartesian plane is made of an infinite number of points: they are everywhere!

    The second quadrant is shaded in the figure below: how many of the four labelled points are there in that shaded area? (Note that the quadrants do not include the axes, just like the inequality x>0x>0 does not include the number zero.)

    There are no labelled points in the second quadrant.

    The correct answer from the list of choices is: no points.

Coordinate pairs on the Cartesian plane

The picture below shows the Cartesian plane and two points. The points are labelled AA and BB.

What are the coordinates of point BB?

INSTRUCTION: Type your answer as a coordinate pair in brackets, with the values separated by a semi-colon e.g. (x; y)
Answer: The coordinates of point BB are:
coordinate
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

You need to find the xx-coordinate of the point and the yy-coordinate of the point. These numbers show how far the point is from the origin.

STEP: Read the coordinates of the point from the graph
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to find the coordinates of point BB. That means we want to know the xx and yy values which tell us where the point is. In other words, we need to know how far the point is from the origin.

We can find these numbers like the arrows show in the picture below: the arrow pointing to the xx-axis shows that the xx-coordinate is 66. The arrow pointing to the yy-axis shows that the yy-coordinate is 33.

Notice that the xx-value shows you how far left or right the point is from the origin, while the yy-value shows how high up or down the point is from the origin.

Remember the order of coordinate pairs: (x;y)(x;y). The xx-coordinate is first and the yy-coordinate is second.

The coordinates of point BB are: (6;3)(6;3).

Submit your answer as:

Points on the Cartesian plane

The picture below shows the Cartesian plane and four points: A,B,CA,B,C, and DD.

Which of the points is at (−4;−2)(−4;−2)?

Answer: The point at (−4;−2)(−4;−2) is:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Coordinate pairs always show the xx-value first and the yy-value second. That means that the coordinates (−4;−2)(−4;−2) refer to the point where x=−4x=−4 and y=−2y=−2.

STEP: Locate the position of (−4;−2)(−4;−2), starting at the origin
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We must decide which of the points has the coordinates (−4;−2)(−4;−2). Remember that coordinate pairs always show the xx-coordinate first and the yy-coordinate second. Therefore (−4;−2)(−4;−2) means that x=−4x=−4 and y=−2y=−2.

We always start at the origin, which is the point in the centre where the xx-axis and the yy-axis meet. From there, the coordinates tell us how far to go and in which directions:

  • the xx-coordinate tells us how far to move left or right (along the xx-axis); if x=0x=0, do not move left or right
  • the yy-coordinate tells us how far to move up or down (along the yy-axis); if y=0y=0, do not move up or down

The arrows below show how to get from the origin to the coordinates (−4;−2)(−4;−2).

Start with the xx value. For the coordinates (−4;−2)(−4;−2), xx is −4−4: that means go 44 steps to the left (we go left because the coordinate is negative). After the xx coordinate, we do what the yy coordinate tells us to do: the yy coordinate is −2−2, which means we need to go down 22 spaces (we go down because the coordinate is negative).

You can see that none of the four points shown in the question are at the position (−4;−2)(−4;−2). Therefore, the correct choice is " None of the above."

Submit your answer as:

Minimum and maximum values of points on the Cartesian plane

Four points are graphed on the Cartesian plane. They are labelled A,B,CA,B,C, and DD. Answer the two questions below about these points.

  1. Which point or points have the minimum xx-value?
  2. What is the minimum xx-value of the point(s) you chose to answer Question 1?
Answer:
  1. The point or points which have the minimum xx-value are: .
  2. The minimum xx-value is: .
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

The question asks about the minimum xx-value for the four points shown: that means the points furthest to the left.

STEP: Look for the points with the minimum xx-value
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

We need to find the minimum xx-value of the four points on the graph. Remember that the xx-coordinate describes the position of a point to the left or right of the origin. The "minimum xx-value" means the point furthest to the left on the graph.

The vertical line below shows the boundary at the minimum xx-value. As explained on the graph, there are no points to the right of this boundary line: that is why the line represents the minimum xx-value of the four points.

There is only one point at the minimum xx-value: C.

STEP: Read the minimum xx-value from the Cartesian plane
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Finding the minimum xx-value for the four points comes straight from the graph above: the vertical line shows the minimum value, which is x=−8x=−8!

This means that the point C has a xx-coordinate equal to −8−8 and none of the other four points have xx-coordinates less than −8−8.

The minimum xx-value for the four points on the graph is x=−8x=−8.

Exercises

Points on the Cartesian plane

The picture below shows the Cartesian plane and four points. The points are labelled A,B,CA,B,C and DD.

Which of the points has the coordinates (0;1)(0;1)?

Answer: The point at (0;1)(0;1) is:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Coordinate pairs always show the xx-value first and the yy-value second. That means that the coordinates (0;1)(0;1) refer to the point where x=0x=0 and y=1y=1.

STEP: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

There are four points shown in the picture above, and we must decide which of the points has the coordinates (0;1)(0;1). Coordinate pairs always show the xx-coordinate first and the yy-coordinate second. In this case that means that x=0x=0 and y=1y=1.

To find where the point is, we always start at the centre point, which is called the "origin." From there, the coordinates tell us how far to go and in which directions:

  • the xx-coordinate tells us how far to move left or right (along the xx-axis); if x=0x=0, do not move left or right
  • the yy-coordinate tells us how far to move up or down (along the yy-axis); if y=0y=0, do not move up or down

There is an arrow on the graph below which shows how to get from the origin to the point at the coordinates (0;1)(0;1).

Start with the xx value. For the coordinates (0;1)(0;1), xx is 00: that means go zero steps left or right - do not go anywhere! After the xx coordinate, we do what the yy coordinate tells us to do: the yy coordinate is 11, which means we need to go up 11 spaces (we go up because the coordinate is positive).

The point at the coordinates (0;1)(0;1) is point A.

Coordinates on the Cartesian plane

Four points, labelled M,N,PM,N,P and QQ, are shown below. Answer the two questions below based on this figure.

  1. What is the yy-coordinate of Point NN?

    Answer: The yy-coordinate of Point NN is:
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Notice that you only the yy-coordinate for the point. Remember that the yy-value for the point tells you how far up or down the point is from the origin.

    STEP: Start at the origin and find the yy-coordinate of Point NN
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need the yy-coordinate of Point NN. There are different ways to think about this question, so you might solve it differently to the explanation here.

    Remember that the yy-coordinate for the point tells us how far up or down the point is from the origin. The horizontal line below passes through Point NN: we can use the line to figure out how far down the point is from the origin.

    As noted in the picture, the horizontal line shows that Point NN is 66 spaces below the origin. In fact, any point on that line is 66 spaces below the origin. That means that the yy-coordinate must be −6−6.

    The yy-coordinate of Point NN is: y=−6y=−6.

    Submit your answer as:

  2. How many points are there in the fourth quadrant?

    Answer: The number of points is:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
    The question asks how many points there are in the fourth quadrant. Remember that it does not matter if a point is labelled or not: it is still there.
    STEP: Consider the points on the plane
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need to figure out how many points there are in the fourth quadrant. Notice that we want all of the points that sit in the fourth quadrant: it does not matter whether they are labelled or not!

    In this question, the four points M,N,PM,N,P and QQ are labelled, but they are not the only points on the graph. The Cartesian plane is made of an infinite number of points: they are everywhere!

    The fourth quadrant is shaded in the figure below: how many points are there in that shaded area?

    Remember, we are not just counting labelled points: we need to think of every single point there is in the fourth quadrant. The answer is that there are an infinite number of points in the fourth quadrant: everywhere you see that shaded colour in the picture above, there is a point!

    The correct answer from the list of choices is: infinite number of points.

    Submit your answer as:

Coordinates on the Cartesian plane

Four points, labelled M,N,PM,N,P and QQ, are shown below. Answer the two questions below based on this figure.

  1. What is the xx-coordinate of Point MM?

    Answer: The xx-coordinate of Point MM is:
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Notice that you only the xx-coordinate for the point. Remember that the xx-value for the point tells you how far to the left or right the point is from the origin.

    STEP: Start at the origin and find the xx-coordinate of Point MM
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We need the xx-coordinate of Point MM. There are different ways to think about this question, so you might solve it differently to the explanation here.

    Remember that the xx-coordinate for the point tells us how far to the left or right the point is from the origin. The vertical line below passes through Point MM: we can use the line to figure out how far to the right or left the point is from the origin.

    As noted in the picture, the vertical line shows that Point MM did not move left or right from the origin (because it passes through the origin!): it moved zero spaces left or right. That means that the xx-coordinate must be 00.

    The xx-coordinate of Point MM is: x=0x=0.

Coordinate pairs on the Cartesian plane

The picture below shows the Cartesian plane and two points. The points are labelled AA and BB.

What are the coordinates of point BB?

INSTRUCTION: Type your answer as a coordinate pair in brackets, with the values separated by a semi-colon e.g. (x; y)
Answer: The coordinates of point BB are:
coordinate
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

STEP: Read the coordinates of the point from the graph
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We can find these numbers like the arrows show in the picture below: the arrow pointing to the xx-axis shows that the xx-coordinate is −2−2. The arrow pointing to the yy-axis shows that the yy-coordinate is 55.

Points on the Cartesian plane

The picture below shows the Cartesian plane and four points: A,B,CA,B,C, and DD.

Which of the points is at (−6;0)(−6;0)?

Answer: The point at (−6;0)(−6;0) is:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Coordinate pairs always show the xx-value first and the yy-value second. That means that the coordinates (−6;0)(−6;0) refer to the point where x=−6x=−6 and y=0y=0.

STEP: Locate the position of (−6;0)(−6;0), starting at the origin
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We must decide which of the points has the coordinates (−6;0)(−6;0). Remember that coordinate pairs always show the xx-coordinate first and the yy-coordinate second. Therefore (−6;0)(−6;0) means that x=−6x=−6 and y=0y=0.

We always start at the origin, which is the point in the centre where the xx-axis and the yy-axis meet. From there, the coordinates tell us how far to go and in which directions:

  • the xx-coordinate tells us how far to move left or right (along the xx-axis); if x=0x=0, do not move left or right
  • the yy-coordinate tells us how far to move up or down (along the yy-axis); if y=0y=0, do not move up or down

There is an arrow on the graph below which shows how to get from the origin to the point at the coordinates (−6;0)(−6;0).

Start with the xx value. For the coordinates (−6;0)(−6;0), xx is −6−6: that means go 66 steps to the left (we go left because the coordinate is negative). After the xx coordinate, we do what the yy coordinate tells us to do: the yy coordinate is zero, which means that we do not move up or down: just stay put!

The point at the coordinates (−6;0)(−6;0) is point B.

    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    This question asks us to find the output value for the equation y=−5y=−5 when x=−6x=−6.

    This is unusual since the equation does not have xx in it... so where do we put the xx-value? Think of the equation this way: y=0⋅x−5y=0⋅x−5. Clever - we just added zero to the equation! And the coefficient of zero is what makes the xx value irrelevant. The output is always −5−5 no matter what the input value is.

    The missing value from the diagram is the output value of y′=−5y′=−5.

  2. Is (−10;−5)(−10;−5) a solution to the equation y=−5y=−5?
    Answer: The correct solution is:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
    You must test the numbers in the equation to see if the numbers agree with the equation or not!
    STEP: <no title>
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    You have an equation, and you must decide if (−10;−5)(−10;−5) solves the equation. Remember that a solution for the equation has values for xx and yy which "agree with" the equation. If you substitute x=−10x=−10 into the equation and the answer is y=−5y=−5 then (−10;−5)(−10;−5) is a solution to the equation; otherwise it is not.

    Since the equation says that y=−5y=−5, the output value of the equation is always −5−5. The input value does not effect the output value in any way! Does the output value (the yy value) in the ordered pair agree with this or not?

    Yes, it does agree! The xx value is completely unconnected to the output value, and in the ordered pair, y=−5y=−5. Therefore the ordered pair (−10;−5)(−10;−5) is a solution to the equation y=−5y=−5.

    The answer from the list is: Yes, it is a solution.

  2. How many solutions are there for the equation?
    Answer:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    The questions asks how many ways there are to solve the equation y=x2+2y=x2+2. Remember that a solution to the equation is an ordered pair which fits into the equation. In other words, a solution is a combination of xx and yy values which agree with the equation.

    The answer is that there are an infinite number of solutions to the equation! The table of values above shows 66 ordered pairs which solve the equation; however, there are many, many more! xx is always the input value for an equation, and yy is always the output value. For the first question, we need to find the output value which corresponds to the input value of x=4x=4: to find the corresponding output value, we substitute x=4x=4 into the equation.

yplug inx=4⟶yy=x=(4)=4y=xx=4plug in⟶y=(4)y=4

  2. Is (−5;−256)(−5;−256) a solution to the equation y=32x+5y=32x+5?
    Answer: The correct solution is:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
    You must test the numbers in the equation to see if the numbers agree with the equation or not!
    STEP: <no title>
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    You have an equation, and you must decide if (−5;−256)(−5;−256) solves the equation. Remember that a solution for the equation has values for xx and yy which "agree with" the equation. If you substitute x=−5x=−5 into the equation and the answer is y=−256y=−256 then (−5;−256)(−5;−256) is a solution to the equation; otherwise it is not.

Reading graphs: graphs show relationships

The graph below represents the relationship between the amount of time someone works and how much money they get paid. As someone works more hours, they get paid more money.

Notice that there are also 33 points labelled along the line of the graph.

Answer:
  1. Which quantity is the independent variable?
  2. Which part of the graph shows that the amount of money is constant?
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
  1. The first question is about the one of the two things related by this graph: "time" and "amount of money." Which one of them is the independent variable?
  2. For the second question, remember that "constant" means something stays the same... what section of the graph, if any, shows the amount of money is not changing?
STEP: Which quantity is the independent variable?
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The graph shows the relationship between two quanities: "time" and "amount of money." This is the information on the two axes. This question asks which one of them is the independent variable?

The words "independent" and "dependent" refer to the variables in the graph. For any graph, one of the variables is going about its business independently while the other vairable "depends" on the first one. Here is a summary:

  • Independant variable: the variable which is in control; it is always on the xx-axis
  • Dependant variable: the variable that follows (responds to) the independent variable; it is always on the yy-axis
In this graph, the independent variable is time because time just moves along: we cannot control it. The dependent variable is amount of money because it depends on how much time has passed. Therefore, the correct answer is "time worked."

STEP: Which part of the graph shows that the amount of money is constant?
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The second question is about how the amount of money is behaving: "constant" means something stays the same... what section of the graph, if any, shows the amount of money is not changing?

Think about working a job: if the amount of money is not changing, that means you are not getting paid for your work! You would work for some hours but not get any money for it. The is not how things should work, and that is why there is no flat (constant) section on this graph: the entire graph is increasing.

The correct choice from the list is: none of the above.

Reading graphs: connecting the variables

The graph below shows the relationship between the temperature of water in an electic kettle and time passing. (Reminder: the boiling point of water is 100°C100°C.) There are also four points labelled along the line of the graph.

  1. What are the coordinates of Point DD?

    INSTRUCTION: Type your answer in the normal way for coordinate pairs, like this: (1 ; 2). You do not need to put any units in your answer, just numbers.
    Answer: The coordinates of Point DD are: .
    coordinate
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Points on the Cartesian plane always have coordinates like this: (x;y)(x;y). In this graph, "time" is in the place of xx and "temperature" is in the place of yy. You need to find the values of "time" and "temperature" for Point DD.

    STEP: Read the graph
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    We need to find the coordinates for a point on the line. Remember that coordinates on the Cartesian plane always come in the same order: (x;y)(x;y). However, for this graph, "time" is in the place of xx and "temperature" is in the place of yy. That means the coordinates we need are (time;temperature)(time;temperature).

    Point DD is circled below. From the point we need to read the values for the coordinates from each axis.

    Point DD has a time value of 99 minutes and a value of 9090 degrees Celsius for temperature. Therefore, the coordinates of Point DD are: (9;90)(9;90).

    Submit your answer as:

  2. What is the meaning behind the coordinates of Point DD?

    Answer:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Think about the meaning of the numbers: for example, the first number in the coordinate pair represents an amount of time.

    STEP: Interpret the meaning of a coordinate pair
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Remember that a graph shows a relationship between two quantities. A coordinate pair connects two values.

    The coordinate pair (9;90)(9;90) connects time and the temperature. It tells us that when the time is 99 minutes the corresponding temperature is 9090 degrees Celsius.

    Therefore the correct choice is: When the time is 99 minutes, then the temperature is 9090 degrees Celsius.

  1. Estimate how much money Kayla made in the first 4 hours of work.
  2. Approximately how many hours did it take Kayla to earn R40R40?
Answer:
  1. In the first 4 hours, Kayla makes about R .
  2. It takes approximately hours to earn R40R40.
numeric
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Remember that a line on a graph connects information: in this case the line connects how many hours Kayla works to the amount of money she will get. For the first question, find the point on the line where the number of hours is 44.

STEP: First question: How much money Kayla earned in the first 44 hours
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

We need to connect 44 hours of work to the amount of money Kayla earns in that time. The blue line on the graph shows us the connection between the amount of time Kayla works and how much money she gets.

The arrows below show the point which connects 44 hours to the money!

You can see that the amount of money for this point is about R120R120.

The answer to the first question is R120R120. (Any answer between 118118 and 122122 is acceptable.)

STEP: Second question: How many hours does it take Kayla to earn R40R40
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The second question is like the first one, but in reverse: now we need to connect R40R40 of income to the number of hours worked. The point for these values is marked on the line, below.

You can see that the amount of time is somewhere between 11 and 22 hours. We need to estimate to get the answer. It is clear that the answer is less than halway from 11 to 22; so it has to be less than 1,51,5.

To earn R40R40, Kayla needs approximately 1,31,3 hours. (Any answer between 1,11,1 and 1,51,5 is acceptable.)

Reading graphs: graphs show relationships

The graph below represents the relationship between the amount of time someone works and how much money they get paid. As someone works more hours, they get paid more money.

Notice that there are also 33 points labelled along the line of the graph.

Answer:
  1. Which quantity is the independent variable?
  2. Which part of the graph shows the amount of money decreasing?
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
  1. The first question is about the one of the two things related by this graph: "time" and "amount of money." Which one of them is the independent variable?
  2. For the second question, remember that "decreasing" means going down... what part of the graph, if any, shows the amount of money going down?
STEP: Which quantity is the independent variable?
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The graph shows the relationship between two quanities: "time" and "amount of money." This is the information on the two axes. This question asks which one of them is the independent variable?

The words "independent" and "dependent" refer to the variables in the graph. For any graph, one of the variables is going about its business independently while the other vairable "depends" on the first one. Here is a summary:

  • Independant variable: the variable which is in control; it is always on the xx-axis
  • Dependant variable: the variable that follows (responds to) the independent variable; it is always on the yy-axis
In this graph, the independent variable is time because time just moves along: we cannot control it. The dependent variable is amount of money because it depends on how much time has passed. Therefore, the correct answer is "time worked."

STEP: Which part of the graph shows the amount of money decreasing?
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The second question is about how the amount of money is changing: "decreasing" means going down... what part of the graph, if any, shows the amount of money going down?

If the amount of money decreased that would mean that as you work more hours, your boss would actually take money from you! That does not happen, which is why the graph does not decrease at all! In fact, this entire graph is increasing.

The correct choice from the list is: none of the above.

Reading graphs: graphs show relationships

Notice that there are also 33 points labelled along the line of the graph.

Answer:
  1. Which quantity is the independent variable?
  2. Which part of the graph shows the amount of money is increasing?
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
  1. The first question is about the one of the two things related by this graph: "time" and "amount of money." Which one of them is the independent variable?
  2. For the second question, remember that "increasing" means going up... what part of the graph, if any, shows the amount of money going up?
STEP: Which quantity is the independent variable?
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The graph shows the relationship between two quanities: "time" and "amount of money." This is the information on the two axes. This question asks which one of them is the independent variable?

The words "independent" and "dependent" refer to the variables in the graph. For any graph, one of the variables is going about its business independently while the other vairable "depends" on the first one. Here is a summary:

  • Independant variable: the variable which is in control; it is always on the xx-axis
  • Dependant variable: the variable that follows (responds to) the independent variable; it is always on the yy-axis

STEP: Which part of the graph shows the amount of money is increasing?
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The second question is about how the amount of money is changing: "increasing" means going up... what part of the graph, if any, shows the amount of money going up?

Think about what happens when someone is working: usually when they work for longer they will get paid more. In other words, as long as they keep working the amount of money increases. The graph below shows that the amount of money is increasing the entire time; there are two big arrows to point out that the amount of money is going up from Point AA to Point BB and also from Point BB to Point CC.

The correct choice from the list is: from A to B and from B to C.

Reading graphs: graphs show relationships

The graph below shows the relationship between the temperature of water in an electic kettle and time passing. At the beginning, the temperature is 20°C20°C. As time passes, the water heats up until it boils. After boiling, the water cools slowly in the kettle.

Notice that there are also 44 points labelled along the line of the graph.

Answer:
  1. Which quantity is the dependent variable?
  2. Which part of the graph shows that the temperature is constant?
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
  1. The first question is about the one of the two things related by this graph: "time" and "temperature." Which one of them is the dependent variable?
  2. For the second question, remember that "constant" means something stays the same... what section of the graph, if any, shows the temperature is not changing?
STEP: Which quantity is the dependent variable?
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

The graph shows the relationship between two quanities: "time" and "temperature." This is the information on the two axes. This question asks which one of them is the dependent variable?

The words "independent" and "dependent" refer to the variables in the graph. For any graph, one of the variables is going about its business independently while the other vairable "depends" on the first one. Here is a summary:

  • Independant variable: the variable which is in control; it is always on the xx-axis
  • Dependant variable: the variable that follows (responds to) the independent variable; it is always on the yy-axis
In this graph, the independent variable is time because time just moves along: we cannot control it. The dependent variable is temperature because it depends on how much time has passed. Therefore, the correct answer is "temperature."

STEP: Which part of the graph shows that the temperature is constant?
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The second question is about how the temperature is behaving: "constant" means something stays the same... what section of the graph, if any, shows the temperature is not changing?

Remember that when something is constant on a graph, it is a flat line (the gradient is zero). This is the part of the line from Point BB to Point CC: for that part of the line, the temperature is 100°C100°C — it is not going up or down.

The correct choice from the list is: from B to C.
